answers: Henry IV, Part 1 [prompt on Henry IV]
parts: Schieffelin brought the first European starlings to America, which is now home to over 200 million of them. Starlings are mentioned in this history play when Hotspur wonders if he could train one to speak Mortimer’s name.

Schieffelin was one of the first people to import house sparrows to North America. This character notes that “there is special providence in the fall of a sparrow,” a premonition of his death and his last words, “The rest is silence.”
The attempt to introduce skylarks and nightingales proved less successful; both birds are mentioned in a speech by this member of the Capulet family who falls in love with a boy from the Montagues.
Name this field of study of the shape and features of the Earth's surface. This field's human subfield studies the ways that humans interact with and shape their environments.

This geopolitical theorist created the heartland theory of geopolitics, which he outlined in his book The Geographic Pivot of History. This geographer was the first European to ascend Mt. Kenya, where he allegedly massacred his eight Swahili porters.
Mackinder considered the "pivot" to stretch from the Yangtze River in China to this other river. This river rises in the Valdai Hills and has the cities of Kazan and Astrakhan along its shores.

answers: urban area(s) [accept cities or suburban areas or word forms like suburbs; accept urban stream syndrome]
impervious [accept word forms, such as imperviousness]
surface runoff [accept overland flow or agricultural runoff; prompt on (stormwater) discharge]
parts: Name these general locations within which water systems are protected by “low impact development”. Streams in these areas are typically ecologically distinct due to the effects of minimal leaf breakdown and stormwater piping.

Urban stream health has an inversely proportional relationship to the number of surfaces in the area described by this adjective, such as asphalt and concrete. Those structures described by this adjective impede natural water infiltration and redirect stormwater flow.
This general term refers to the excess flow of water across a landscape. This process is a major cause of soil erosion and the deposition of harmful nutrients and chemicals into waterways.

answers: Incan road system [or Qhapaq Nañ; accept anything involving Inca and transportation of some sort]
parts: Name this system where chasquis were often targeted by bandits called pomaranra. Along this system, chasquis stopped at qollqa storehouses to pick up and drop off goods.
Incan roads all originated in this Incan capital city from which the four suyus, or cardinal directions began.
Chasquis runners carried this traditional fermented alcoholic beverage of the Inca. Women called aqlla lived in compounds their entire lives performing ceremonial tasks such as brewing this beverage.

answers: Freud [accept Sigmund Freud or Anna Freud]
parts: Name this psychoanalyst, who argued for the existence of the superego from birth in The Psychoanalysis of Children.

Klein's arguments regarding aggression and child analysis caused a rift between her and a woman with this surname. That psychoanalyst was the daughter of the author of The Interpretation of Dreams, who also shares this surname.

Klein described these two concepts as an opposing kind of "life pulsation" and "death pulsation." Sigmund Freud referred to these two concepts as the driving forces of life, and they are usually translated as the life and death drives.

answers: “I Got Rhythm” [prompt on rhythm changes by asking “What is the name of the song?”]
parts: Name this jazz standard originally from the musical Girl Crazy. Its singer claims “Old Man trouble, I don’t mind him,” and “Who could ask for anything more?”
“I Got Rhythm” was written by Ira and composed by George, a pair of brothers with this last name responsible for the opera Porgy and Bess.
One of the most famous songs to use rhythm changes was this 1946 bebop song written by Charlie Parker after Dizzy Gillespie left his band. Parker supposedly named this song after his heroin dealer.

answers: gel electrophoresis [anti-prompt (“be less specific…”) on (SDS) PAGE]
mobility shift assay [or MC-EMSA or electrophoretic mobility shift assay or mobility shift electrophoresis or gel shift assay or gel retardation assay]
parts: Name this common benchtop technique typically run after PCR to visualize the results. Samples in this technique are loaded into wells in a gel matrix and stained with dyes like ethidium bromide.

When doing a Western blot, a common intermediate step is to stain your sample with Ponceau S and run it on a gel to confirm that you have protein. Ponceau staining creates bands of this color when visualized, which is also the color of the side on a standard electrophoresis box that DNA runs toward.

Electrophoresis is also used in this other assay for analyzing DNA-protein interactions by mixing labeled DNA with a protein of interest, running them on a gel, and observing the namesake result relative to a DNA-only lane.

answers: America [or the United States of America; or USA; accept “Let America Be America Again” or “I, Too, Sing America”]
Langston Hughes [or James Mercer Langston Hughes]
parts: Name this place. The narrator of another poem shows his loyalty to this place by promising to “be at the table / When company comes.”
This author of “Let America Be America Again” and “I, Too, Sing America” was a major figure of the Harlem Renaissance. His poem “Harlem” asks “What happens to a dream deferred?”
In this Langston Hughes poem, the speaker writes “I am the only colored student in my class” after an “instructor” tells him “Go home and write / a page tonight.”

Name this style of painting that emphasized the value of preparatory studies and preliminary drawings. Stylistically, paintings in this style were representative of the Central Italian tradition. Either the Italian or English term is acceptable.

Whereas disegno paintings were emblematic of Central Italian art, the colorito style was championed by painters from this other Italian city. A colorito depiction of this city’s patron saint and its many canals can be seen in Carpaccio’s The Lion of St. Mark.

This art historian described the disegno approach of artists like Michelangelo as the “father of all the visual arts”. That description can be found in his work Lives of the Most Eminent Painters, Sculptors, and Architects.
Name this specific four-word phrase that was displayed across the street from Juneau-Douglas High School during the 2002 Winter Olympics Torch Relay, prompting retaliation from Deborah Morse.

The Supreme Court ruled against Joseph Frederick, the student who held up that poster, denying the Ninth Circuit’s assertion that this previous 1969 case involving black armbands applied in Morse v. Frederick.
The plaintiffs in Tinker were protesting this conflict. This conflict was also protested by the plaintiff in Cohen v. California, who wore a shirt that said “FUCK THE DRAFT”.

answers: One Hundred Years of Solitude [or Cien años de soledad]
parts: Name this novel by Gabriel García Márquez about the residents of Macondo.
Otto Dietrich zur Linde, a concentration camp commandant, writes his unrepentant last testament while awaiting his execution by firing squad in this short story by Jorge Luis Borges (“BOR-hays”).
Tomas Arroyo and the corpse of the title character are shot at by a firing squad at the end of this author’s novel The Old Gringo.

answers: taro [or taro root; or Colocasia esculenta; or dasheen; or yautia; or eddo; or kalo]
parts: Name this trendy Taiwanese drink that typically contains chewy tapioca pearls.

A common variety of bubble tea adds this purple, starchy plant to it. This plant looks similar to a sweet potato, is a staple crop in many Caribbean and Pacific nations, and is used to make the Hawaiian dish poi.
Bubble tea can also be made using this dark tea with a malty flavor that is often used for English breakfast tea. It is named for the northeastern Indian state that contains Kaziranga National Park.

answers: infinite regress [or reductio ad infinitum; prompt on paradoxes]
modus ponens [or modus ponendo ponens; or implication elimination; or conditional elimination or affirming the antecedent]
parts: Name this sort of logical problem, where a justification requires a seemingly  unending series of other justifications in order to be valid.
In that paper, Lewis Carroll argued that this type of argument always leads to an infinite regress. This argument is frequently simplified as "if P implies Q and P is true, then Q must be true."
In a book titled for this mathematician and His Rivals, Lewis Carroll argues that 13 different math textbooks are all inferior to, or state the same thing as, this ancient mathematician's Elements.
Name this general who clashed with the Goths during the Byzantine conquest of Italy. His victories included the Battle of Taginae, where he used a crescent formation to decimate the army of Totila.
Narses plotted with this political figure to assassinate John of Cappadocia. According to Procopius, geese ate barley grains off of this person’s naked body.

Narses became this emperor’s favorite general after the Gothic king Vittigis offered to appoint Belisarius “Emperor of the West”, leading to Belisarius’ falling out of favor at this Byzantine emperor’s court.

answers: positron annihilation spectroscopy [or positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy or PAS or PALS; prompt on partial answers mentioning positrons]
parts: Name this type of spectroscopy that uses its namesake antiparticle to probe defects and voids in solid materials at the sub-nanometer scale.
A common source of positrons for PAS is the unstable 22-isotope of this second-lightest alkali metal. This element shows its bright yellow D-line in a flame test.

Sodium iodide doped with thallium is the most widely-used crystalline material in these particle detectors that emit low energy photons when hit by high-energy particles that are collected and amplified in photomultiplier tubes.

answers: Suzuki Shinichi [accept Suzuki method; do not accept or prompt on "Shinichi"]
Guido of Arezzo [prompt on partial answer]
parts: This Japanese violinist’s namesake method begins with variations on "twinkle twinkle little star" before going on to cover the works of Telemann, Dvorak, and Paganini, among others.

This composer's Schulwerk system for musical education makes heavy use of percussion instruments and group chants for children. A choir singing "O Fortuna” opens this composer’s cantata Carmina Burana.

This 11th century monk and pioneering Italian musicologist is credited with proposing the six syllable solmization system, modern staff notation, and a namesake mnemonic system of hand signs that would be heavily incorporated into many modern methods for teaching music.
Name this character who espouses "metaphysico-theologo-cosmolonigology" as a parody of the philosopher Gottfried Leibniz. He teaches his students that they live in “the best of all possible worlds.”
Dr. Pangloss appears in this French author’s novel Candide.
A kind-hearted character named James or Jacques, who belongs to this religious sect, falls overboard during the Lisbon earthquake in Candide.

answers: combination rules [combining rules; prompt on rules alone]
parts: Name these statements that provide the interaction energy component for two non-bonded atoms. Another set of these statements named for Kong improve upon the Lorentz-Berthelot ones.
Combination rules are relevant to this computer simulation technique, in which Newton’s equations of motions are used to model the physical properties and movements of atoms in complex systems.

Combination rules are particularly useful in simulations of the interaction potential named for this Dutch chemist. This chemist also lends his name to an equation of state that adds terms a and b to the ideal gas law.

answers: haloes [or nimbus; or aureole; or glory; or gloriole]
parts: Name these religious artworks used in Catholic and Orthodox Churches, which depict saints or other figures of veneration. Byzantine emperor Leo III initiated some of these artworks' namesake "oclasms."
Icons depicting this figure are sometimes covered by a riza that includes a crown. This figure is known as Theotokos in Eastern Orthodox Churches.
Rizas often contain highly elaborate depictions of these religious art motifs. When displayed on Jesus, these motifs frequently contain the letters omicron, omega, and nu.

answers: International Red Cross [or International Movement of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; accept American Red Cross]
Napoleon III [accept Charles-Louis Napoléon Bonaparte; do NOT prompt on “Napoleon”]
parts: Name this man who was awarded a 1901 prize alongside Frederic Passy. The women of Castiglione feature prominently in his memoir A Memory of Solferino.
Dunant founded this international relief society after witnessing the bloodbath at Solferino. The American analog of this organization was founded by Clara Barton.

The bloodshed at Solferino led this ruler to seek peace through the Armistice of Villafranca. This leader and his uncle were referenced in Marx’s quote “History repeats itself, first as tragedy, then as farce”.
